newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU Commission releases Alitalia aid probe details.
newsitem.headline: EU Commission releases Alitalia aid probe details.

text.p: The European Commission published on Tuesday further detail of its probe into a planned 3,313 billion lire ($2.2 billion) aid package and restructuring plan for Italy's mainly state-owned carrier Alitalia.

The 11-page document, published in the EU's Official Journal, confirmed the Commission's October 9 announcement of the inquiry, which it launched after rejecting Alitalia's case for a bail-out partly funded by the state.

The Commission said then it was unconvinced by the Rome government's arguments and added on Tuesday that it would hire external consultants to comb through the proposed restructuring plan in order to suggest changes.

"These changes could include the additional sale of assets, the spreading out of the capital increases, a further reduction in operating costs, an active search for foreign partners, adjustment of the proposed expansion, etc." the EU executive said in the Official Journal.

Alitalia told the Commission of its intended cash injection last July, saying that an immediate 1.5 trillion lire would be paid by its largest shareholder, the state-owned holding company Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale (IRI).
The Commission rejected this on the grounds that Alitalia's private investors, who hold 10 percent of the airline stock, showed no indication of stumping up any money.
Italy has one month to answer the various questions raised by the Commission, the Official Journal said. $=1510 lire
